svg:
``
Hi Alessia, can we talk about the difference between a zoo and a circus? Yes, happy to chat! I’m not really an expert though.That’s fine! I just wanted to hear your thoughts. So, what’s the first thing that comes to your mind when you think of a zoo? Um… animals in cages, I guess? Like lions, monkeys, that sort of thing. It’s where people go to see animals.Right, and what about a circus? That’s more like… clowns and acrobats, and sometimes animals doing tricks. Though I don’t think I’ve seen one with animals since I was a kid.Yeah, that makes sense. The main difference is that zoos are usually focused on taking care of animals, showing how they live, and sometimes helping endangered species.
Circuses, especially in the past, used ani-mals more for entertainment, making them do tricks for a prize. Oh, I never really thought about that. I guess the ani mals in circuses did not live a happy life.Exactly. A lot of them were kept in small cages and traveled constantly. That’s really stressful for wild animals. That’s why many places have banned animal acts in circuses now. That’s a good thing. Are zoos perfect then?Not always. Some zoos don’t have great conditions either. But the better ones try to create natural habitats and educate people about the animals. The differen-ce is mostly in how the animals get trea-ted. Got it. What about the Dolfinarium?
The Dolfinarium is interesting because it’s not quite a zoo, but also not a traditional circus. They focus on sea animals, mainly dolphins, and they do shows with them. Right, like when the dolphins jump and spin in the air on command.Yeah, and that’s where the debate starts. Some people say those shows are entertaining and educational, but others feel like it’s too close to circus-style performances and not respect-ful of the animals' natural behavior. Hmm. I guess if the dolphins are doing tricks just for the audience, it kind of feels more like a circus.Exactly. The question is whether those shows actually help people learn, or if it’s just enter-tainment with animals doing unnatural things. Makes sense. I guess I never really thought about it before. It's kind of
in the middle.That’s a good way to put it. And that's why it’s such a debated topic. Some people think places like the Dolfinarium should change and focus more on conservation and less on shows. Yeah, especially now that people are more aware of animal rights.Yes, an issue raised by activists of Bite Back and Active for Justice is the ongoing use of dolphins and sea lions in performances. They say that trainers are still allowed to surf on the dolphins' noses and make sea lions wave their flippers at the audience. These actions violate agreements made with the government regarding the use of animals for entertainment. Using the animals in this way would make the park more like a circus than a zoo then.Definitely. And using animals for entertai-
ment is illegal in the Netherlands. But the Dolfinarium is considered a zoo by the government. They hide behind the fact that they do school trips and are here to educa-te children on the dolphins. But if they're a zoo they should actually stop the shows then.Yes, in theory they should. And let's not even get into the living conditions of the animals. They live in small tanks only 5 meters deep. But if a dolphin jumps or swims how do they not hurt themselves?Well, the animals are smart so they won't just bump into a wall. But they do get very bored. And if dolphins get bored, they will swim on their back and clap with their mouths. That's so sad.
Yes, it is very sad. And you will never be able to tell as a visitor that a dolphin is sad, because their faces are stunted in a way that they are always smiling.Poor animals. Thank you for telling me this.No problem. And let’s hope these animals will get better circumstances soon.
Hi Alessia, can we talk about the difference between a zoo and a circus? Yes, happy to chat! I’m not really an expert though.That’s fine! I just wanted to hear your thoughts. So, what’s the first thing that comes to your mind when you think of a zoo? Um… animals in cages, I guess? Like lions, monkeys, that sort of thing. It’s where people go to see animals.Right, and what about a circus? That’s more like… clowns and acrobats, and sometimes animals doing tricks. Though I don’t think I’ve seen one with animals since I was a kid.Yeah, that makes sense. The main difference is that zoos are usually focused on taking care of animals, showing how they live, and sometimes helping endangered species.
Circuses, especially in the past, used ani-mals more for entertainment, making them do tricks for a prize. Oh, I never really thought about that. I guess the ani mals in circuses did not live a happy life.Exactly. A lot of them were kept in small cages and traveled constantly. That’s really stressful for wild animals. That’s why many places have banned animal acts in circuses now. That’s a good thing. Are zoos perfect then?Not always. Some zoos don’t have great conditions either. But the better ones try to create natural habitats and educate people about the animals. The differen-ce is mostly in how the animals get trea-ted. Got it. What about the Dolfinarium?
The Dolfinarium is interesting because it’s not quite a zoo, but also not a traditional circus. They focus on sea animals, mainly dolphins, and they do shows with them. Right, like when the dolphins jump and spin in the air on command.Yeah, and that’s where the debate starts. Some people say those shows are entertaining and educational, but others feel like it’s too close to circus-style performances and not respect-ful of the animals' natural behavior. Hmm. I guess if the dolphins are doing tricks just for the audience, it kind of feels more like a circus.Exactly. The question is whether those shows actually help people learn, or if it’s just enter-tainment with animals doing unnatural things. Makes sense. I guess I never really thought about it before. It's kind of
in the middle.That’s a good way to put it. And that's why it’s such a debated topic. Some people think places like the Dolfinarium should change and focus more on conservation and less on shows. Yeah, especially now that people are more aware of animal rights.Yes, an issue raised by activists of Bite Back and Active for Justice is the ongoing use of dolphins and sea lions in performances. They say that trainers are still allowed to surf on the dolphins' noses and make sea lions wave their flippers at the audience. These actions violate agreements made with the government regarding the use of animals for entertainment. Using the animals in this way would make the park more like a circus than a zoo then.Definitely. And using animals for entertai-
ment is illegal in the Netherlands. But the Dolfinarium is considered a zoo by the government. They hide behind the fact that they do school trips and are here to educa-te children on the dolphins. But if they're a zoo they should actually stop the shows then.Yes, in theory they should. And let's not even get into the living conditions of the animals. They live in small tanks only 5 meters deep. But if a dolphin jumps or swims how do they not hurt themselves?Well, the animals are smart so they won't just bump into a wall. But they do get very bored. And if dolphins get bored, they will swim on their back and clap with their mouths. That's so sad.
Yes, it is very sad. And you will never be able to tell as a visitor that a dolphin is sad, because their faces are stunted in a way that they are always smiling.Poor animals. Thank you for telling me this.No problem. And let’s hope these animals will get better circumstances soon.
Dolfinarium
Harderwijk
